Quoting Nilesh Thali <nilesh.thali@...>:

> > (2) Your tests are simple: populate the database with data, write News
> beans
> > that represent that data, assert that getAllNews() answers the same
> Set (or
> > List, if you care about order within the collection) of News beans. Do
> this
> > with as many different datasets as you need to be confident that your
> method
> > works.
> 
>     only problem with testing queries like this is that your test will
> be time and
>     database dependent, because data (in this case the number of news
> beans)
>     may change over time, and you will see the red bar even though your
> method
>     works fine.

If your test creates data, then tries to query it, then deletes the data, then 
at least the time depedency goes away.

>     There is a line of thought that all you need to do is make sure your
> SQL
>     is valid. beyond that you're testing your database, not your
> method...

Not quite. The REAL stuff to test is creating a News object from a ResultSet. 
You could use a MockResultSet for that, but then you'd need to simulate the 
database sending you back data in ways you didn't expect. For example, DECIMAL 
is BigDecimal under Oracle and Double under DB2. Unless you're willing to code 
that knowledge into your MockResultSet, you're better off testing against real 
ResultSet objects coming from your trusty JDBC driver. For that reason, testing 
against a live database is preferred.

That said, you can have a separate test suite for your live database tests and 
run them only (1) when you build a DataAccessObject; (2) when Cruisecontrol 
runs all your tests for you.
